(Late Publication)

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL POSITION IN COLONY
(Request for statement)


    8. Mr John Ede asked the Financial Secretary whether he will make a statement on the present economic and financial position in the Colony.

    Mr T. M. Hart: Sir, I have been asked to make a statement on the economic and financial position of Singapore at the present time and I welcome the opportunity of being able to do so.

Column: 429



    There is, Sir, little doubt that Singapore is at present experiencing a recession in trade. There are on all sides complaints of difficulties in moving stocks, of restrictions in normal entrepot outlets, of tightness of money and difficult trading conditions generally. There is, however, more concrete evidence in other directions. There has been a certain contraction in the circulation of currency and over the past two months banks have purchased some $30 million worth of sterling. Customs duty receipts have fallen below the estimates in some directions and are barely holding their own in others. There has been a marked falling off in the consumption of liquor and receipts have fallen some $2,300,000 below the estimate for the first six months of the year. Petrol duty receipts have also fallen below the estimate by about half a million dollars and although consumption still increases, the rate of increase is considerably below that of pravious years. Receipts from entertainment duty are slightly ahead of the estimate but here again the rate of increase in the purchase of cinema seats is lower than in previous years. The number of new motor cars registered has also fallen considerably below the level for the same period last year. On the other hand, the consumption of tobacco appears to have gone up but this may be due more to the successful efforts of the Customs Department in suppressing smuggling than to any real increase in consumption. Again, there is an even more marked reluctance to pay income tax and company tax this year than last year when tardiness also gave some cause for concern. All these facts point clearly to the existence of a recession in trade.

    It is impossible to say with any certainty what course the recession is likely to take in the future. Too many imponderables are involved. There are indications of an improvement in conditions in the United States of America and elsewhere and there is perhaps reason to hope that the corner has been turned in these countries. There are also encouraging signs in the local economy. The price of the higher grades of rubber

Column: 430

has been maintained and rubber interests seem confident that the price of other grades will improve as the year progresses. Statistics suggest that the trade with Indonesia has been well maintained. There are therefore perhaps grounds for reasonable optimism about the future. At the same time, just as the effects of the world trade reces sion are delayed in reaching Singapore, so recovery is also delayed, although to a lesser extent. Therefore, even if the corner has been turned in the United States and elsewhere, we must expect the present recession to be with us for some time yet. It might be well into next year before the effects are finally thrown off. On the other hand, events could quite easily take place which might deepen and prolong the present recession. In the unsettled state of the world today, it is difficult to be certain of anything.

    When, Sir, it became clear that Singapore was going to be affected by the general recession in world trade, the Government decided to take stock of its position. As hon. Members are aware, a considerable proportion of the Government revenue is derived from sources which are affected to varying degrees by fluctuations in trade. Forty-five per cent of the revenue comes from duties on liquor, tobacco, petroleum, entertainment and betting. The yield from all these sources is affected to a certain extent by contraction of spending power which is often due to a recession in trade. Twenty-five per cent of the revenue comes from income tax and company tax. The yield from this source is directly related to earnings which in turn are directly related to the state of trade. In the circumstances, it will be appreciated that even a mild recession in trade must have some effect on revenue. A serious and prolonged recession could have a corresponding effect.

    Hon. Members will recall that when presenting the Budget for 1958, I said that provided there was no marked recession in trade and provided that Government expenditure and applications for supplementary vote were kept to an

Column: 431

absolute minimum, revenue and expenditure should balance at the end of the year. It will therefore be appreciated that even a slight contraction of revenue could upset this balance and that a serious contraction could have a serious effect.

    Hon. Members are also aware that the very ambitious development plans which Government has in hand are financed to a considerable extent each year by a contribution from revenue in addition to the development fund and surplus funds. Any marked contraction of revenue would limit the capacity of Government to make these contributions and might have serious effects on the implementation of the development plans. Again in this connection, the implementation of these plans gathered momentum in the latter part of 1957. More work was done and more money was spent than was expected. This in turn meant that the balance of the development fund carried forward into 1958 was smaller than estimated and meant that a greater proportion of the surplus funds available will have to be used to finance development in 1958.

    That, Sir, then was the background against which the Government took stock of its position in the light of the uncertain economic situation. Now, Sir, perhaps I may be allowed to explain what action Government took as a result of its stock-taking.

    With regard to the recurrent expenditure position, it seemed clear that there must be at least a slight contraction of revenue in 1958. On the other hand, the possibility was that it might not be very large, and the returns for expenditure for the early months of the year suggested that the estimates for expenditure which were made in December of last year would not be very far out. The most obvious way to offset this possible slight contraction of revenue was to cut expenditure and it was therefore decided to make a determined drive to reduce expenditure in the various departments within their portfolios. All vacant posts in the Establishment were frozen until

Column: 432

Ministers had an opportunity to re-examine the need for them in the light of a change in the economic position. Proposals for special expenditure were treated in the same way. The recurrent expenditure in departments of Government was examined with great care to see what economies could be effected. This examination has proved to be a long and laborious business and has not yet been completed. On the other hand, sufficient information is now available to suggest that considerable economies can be effected and that these may go a considerable way towards offsetting the effects of any contraction of revenue which may take place in 1958. In short, therefore, when the accounts are made up, it may well be found that the deficit between actual revenue and expenditure in 1958 is comparatively small.

    The position with regard to 1959 perhaps gives cause for a little more concern. As I have explained, the effect of any recession in trade on income and company tax returns is delayed and any marked decrease in individual earnings and company profit in 1958 could have a considerable effect on revenue from income and company tax in 1959. It has not so far been possible to obtain any reliable information on these points or to obtain any idea of the position in the Colony as a whole. I can however assure hon. Members that this particular question is engaging the close and constant attention of the Government and that whatever steps may be necessary to meet any situation which may develop will be taken.

    With regard to development, as hon. Members are aware, the Government is already heavily committed in respect of development plans which all Parties are agreed are essential for the well-being of the people of Singapore. The implementation of these plans will stretch the resources of Singapore to the limit. Any shortfall of funds from any source which has been taken into account in planning might have an embarrassing effect. It was therefore essential to consider the possible consequences of any shortfall

Column: 433

of contributions from revenue and contraction of reserves and to make sure that the Government was not over-committed.

    Work in hand, Sir, at the present time will involve the expenditure of well over $70 million in 1958. This is more than has ever before been spent in one year on development and represents the fulfilment of all the Government's planning for the development of education, medical and health facilities, communications and public housing over the past three years. About $24 million will be spent by the Public Works Depart ment on capital works including the Polytechnic. About $22 million will be spent by the Singapore Improvement Trust on public housing. $5 million will be spent by the Singapore Telephone Board on telephone development; $4 million on rural development; $7 million on the purchase of sites for schools, etc, and on the resettlement of squatters, and the balance on miscellaneous special development expenditure. Expenditure of this order by Government will go a very long way to offset the effects of a recession in the building and allied trades and in many other directions in 1958.

    With regard to next year, work and services now in hand but uncompleted at the end of this year will necessitate expenditure of about $24 million in 1959. Of this total sum, $16 million will represent capital work by the Public Works Department. There will also be other unavoidable commitments of which account must be taken. These commitments will total a sum of $30 million including some $15 million for public housing, $4 million for rural development, $2 million for telecommunications development, and so on. In brief, work in hand at the end of 1958 and additional commitments of a general nature which must be added in 1959 will involve expenditure in that year of the order of $55 million. This is a very sizeable sum and represents a level of development expenditure well up to that of previous years. It will go

Column: 434

a long way to offset any effects of the present recession which may still persist in 1959.

    All things considered, no serious difficulty is anticipated in financing these programmes. At the same time, until such time as the probable course of the recession and its possible effects on the revenues of the Colony are quite clear, care will obviously have to be taken not to enter into any fresh commitments which might subsequently be found to be embarrassing. With this in mind, Ministers are at present examining the list of additional items of public works which could possibly be started this year with a view to determining those which should be proceeded with forthwith and those which are of less importance and which can safely be kept back until a later date. It is hoped that this examination will be completed at an early date.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, while we are grateful to the Hon. the Financial Secretary for his lengthy reply, is he aware that there is grave dissatisfaction in industrial circles at the failure of the Government to lay down a clear and unequivocal policy of support to local industry and that this is one reason for the economic setback?

    Mr Hart: I would like to have notice of that question.

DISTRICT COUNCIL ELECTIONS
(Date)


    10. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing if he will give a definite date for the District Council Elections.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Hon. Members will observe that a new Bill intituled the Local Government Elections (Amendment) Ordinance, 1958 is being introduced today. This Bill embodies recom mendations made in the Elias Report with regard to the conduct and holding of elections. As soon as after this amending Ordinance is enacted and comes into force, it is intended that elections to the District Councils will take place according to the statutory timetable pro.vided for in the Local Government Elections Ordinance, that is by the issue of writ followed by nomination day and finally polling day. The definite timetable will be announced once this amending Bill becomes law.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, can the Minister tell us how long it will take rather than to give a vague reply that it will take place in accordance with the timetable provided for in the Ordinance?

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, this amending legislation will go to Select Committee and I therefore cannot anticipate how long the Select Committee will take in its deliberations but soon after the legislation becomes law, only then can the Government give a definite date.

COMPLAINTS BY TENANTS OF S.I.T.
HOUSES ON JALAN TECK WHYE ESTATE


    11. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing if he is aware of the representations made by the tenants of Singapore Improvement Trust houses on Jalan Teck Whye Estate to the Assistant Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing on 17th May, 1958, complaining of:-

    (i) excessive heat;

    (ii) lack of secure protection of the windows;

    (iii) clogging of drains by sand and mud; and

    (iv) roof leakages;

and if he will state what action he will take, or has taken, in this matter.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Yes, Sir, I am aware of these complaints. In fact, the site was visited by the Acting Minister, the Assistant Minister and the Chairman of the Singapore Improvement Trust who inspected the area and discussed the complaints with the residents on 17th May, 1958. Action has been taken by the Singapore Improvement Trust to deal with (ii), (iii) and (iv). With regard to (i), it must be pointed out that the type of single storey units in this estate belongs to the low cost category. The Singapore Improvement Trust have omitted ceilings from such houses as a matter of policy in order to keep the rents low but if tenants wish to install them at their own expense, the Trust would be prepared to grant permission. In fact, Sir, permission has already been granted to all such applicants.

    It has been ascertained from scientific experiments however that ceilings would not reduce the temperature by more than two degrees. A number of shady

trees have already been planted in this estate and when they mature there will be a great improvement in the matter of temperature. Planting of further trees is being carried out in an effort to in crease protection from the sun but tenants can also help themselves by growing shady plants outside their houses.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Naturally, not by laymen like me, Sir.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: No, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Lee Choon Eng.

REPRESENTATION BY ASSEMBLYMEN ON COURT OF UNIVERSITY OF MALAYA


    12. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Education if he is aware that there are no representatives of the Legislative Assembly of Singapore on the Court of the University of Malaya, and if he will state when the election will be held by this Assembly.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am very glad that the Member for Queenstown has asked me this question of representatives of this Assembly on the Court of the University of Malaya as this same question has been engaging my attention for some time.

Column: 438



    I have discussed this matter with several people and have indeed gone into the matter very carefully. I have been advised that it seems rather invidious that Members of the Legislative Assembly including Opposition Members should be appointed to the University Court as when an occasion arises and an Assemblyman wishes to criticise or query the Court, it would mean that the Opposition would in fact be criticising or querying itself.

    There is also the other question of the future of the University and its division between Singapore and the Federation of Malaya which requires looking into. In the circumstances, I propose to deal with this question of the Assembly's representation on the University Court at the same time as I will be dealing with the future of the University and its new constitution which will arise because of the proposed division of the University.

SINGAPORE TELEPHONE BOARD'S 1956 ANNUAL REPORT
(Publication of fuller report)


    13. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Minister for Communications and Works why the Singapore Telephone Board's Annual Report for the year 1956 does not give more relevant information about the operations of the Board and its financial position for the year 1956, and whether he will take steps to see that a fuller report for 1956 is published.

    Mr Francis Thomas: As pointed out in paragraph 14 of the S.T.B. Report under the heading 'Finance' the amount to be paid for the undertaking has not yet been agreed and consequently it is not possible to prepare comprehensive accounts which would give reliable information about the financial position of the Board. The hon. Member will appreciate that the actual cost of the undertaking is an essential basic factor in the light of which other accounting figures must be interpreted. I do not think that the Board should publish accounts from which this basic factor is omitted as they might be extremely misleading.

Column: 439



    If the hon. Member will indicate to me what non-financial information he desires about the operations of the Board in 1956, I will see whether I can get it for him from the Board. Under the Ordinance however it is not within my power to send back to the Board its Report with instructions that it should be amplified.

    The hon. Member will note that the Report in question is for 1956. If he will let me know what he considers should be in the 1957 Report, I can consider it and give what I think are suitable directions to the Board with regard to its 1957 Report. I hope in any case that it may be possible for the 1957 Report to give an indication of some of the financial aspects of the Board's operations.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does the Minister for Transport and Communications understand that this House is at least entitled to as much information on the operations of the Board as any shareholder of a private company is entitled to, on the operations of a private limited company?

    Mr Francis Thomas: I would in general agree to that proposition, Mr Speaker, but it does not alter the fact that if the price is not finalised, you cannot finalise your basic accounts.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: He agreed with my first proposition; does he of not agree that the Report as published gives us no information whatsoever as to the operational expenses of the Board for the year in question?

    Mr Francis Thomas: I would refer the hon. Member to my first answer to the question. The 1957 Report will be available in the not so distant future and we can consider what should be in that Report.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: We are now discussing the 1956 Report and what I would like to know from the Minister is why were the operational accounts excluded from this Report? Surely, apart from the question of the compensation to be paid to the O.T.E.C. and the price
